message_1: What is the maximum order a Latin square can have if each entry can only take values from the set {1, 2, 3} and no two entries in the same row or column can take the same value?
message_2:
A Latin square of order n is an n x n array filled with n different symbols, each occurring exactly once in each row and each column. In this case, the set of symbols is {1, 2, 3}. 

Since there are only 3 different symbols, the maximum order a Latin square can have in this case is 3. This is because if we try to create a Latin square of order 4 or larger, we would need at least 4 different symbols to fill the rows and columns without repeating any symbol in the same row or column.

Here's an example of a Latin square of order 3 using the given set {1, 2, 3}:

1 2 3
2 3 1
3 1 2
